awd_titl_txt: NSF Wireless Spectrum R&D Senior Steering Group Workshop (WSRD)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Wireless Spectrum R&D (WSRD) Senior Steering Group (SSG) of the National Information Technology R&D (NITRD) program was stood up as a result of the president's June 2010 memorandum on "Unleashing the Wireless Broadband Revolution." WSRD's purpose is to implement section 3 of the presidential memorandum, which directs the Secretary of Commerce, "in consultation with the National Institute of Standards and Technology, National Science Foundation (NSF), the Department of Defense, the Department of Justice, NASA, and other agencies as appropriate, [to] create and implement a plan to facilitate research, development, experimentation, and testing by researchers to explore innovative spectrum-sharing technologies, including those that are secure and resilient." WSRD facilitates coordination and information exchange regarding federal government research in the spectrum domain. 

Although WSRD is a committee of the federal government, it closely coordinates its activities with private industry, public safety, academic researchers, and state and local governments, as these sectors are major drivers of spectrum requirements, research, and development. It does so through a series of workshops that includes the participation of representatives of all of these groups. Three workshops have been held so far: The first in Boulder, CO, in July 2011, which concentrated on coordinating the current and future federal spectrum R&D portfolio within the broader context; the second in Berkeley, CA, in January 2012, which undertook a discussion of the need for a national-level wireless testbed capability; and the third in Boulder, CO, in July 2012, which concentrated on identifying specific research topics central to breaking the dynamic spectrum access stalemate between incumbents and innovative new spectrum users. 

A challenge with the first two workshops was getting adequate and diverse representation from some sectors, because of the lack of travel funds. In the third workshop, and the workshop proposed here, limited travel funds are available to invited participants who might otherwise have difficulty attending. Priority will be given to improving the gender and racial diversity of the workshop participants. The travel grant program will be led by Dr. Bill Lehr of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who is the lead member of the workshop organizing committee.

por.por_cntn:
The continued growth and health of wireless services, including wireless broadband, are critical for the health of the U.S. economy. This growth is challenged by the scarcity of radio frequency spectrum resources. To address this challenge, the National Broadband Plan and a Presidential Memorandum have called for expanding commercial access to an additional 500MHz of spectrum. Enabling this access will require expanding shared spectrum access. In recent decades, wireless technologists have developed a host of new technologies that expand the capacity of existing wireless resources, enabling those resources to be shared and utilized more intensively.

In 2010, the Secretary of Commerce established the Wireless Spectrum Research and Development Senior Steering Group (WSRD SSG) to assist the Secretary in creating and implementing a plan to facilitate research, development, experimentation, and testing to explore innovative spectrum-sharing technologies. As part of this endeavor, WSRD has organized a regular series of workshops to bring together researchers, policymakers, and industry stakeholders to formulate research agendas and to collaborate on solutions. The first three workshops focused on technical research.

The purpose of this award was to fund a 4th WSRD workshop focused on identifying the economic and policy research needed to commercialize novel sharing technologies and advance the goal of expanding spectrum sharing. This workshop was hosted at MIT in April 2013 and provided a venue for key individuals from industry, academia, and the public sector, including WSRD members, to discuss and help frame the multidisciplinary economic and policy research needed to complement technical R&D endeavors that are consistent with the Federal Government‘s role in sponsoring “high-risk high-reward” research innovation and experimentation. The funds were used to provide partial travel support for invited non-federal-government participants and to cover such workshop related costs as preparation of the post-conference report, video, and other sundry conference related expenses. 

The workshop provided a valuable networking opportunity for the research community and helped identify a range of R&D projects -- both on-going and projected -- that will contribute to the realization of WSRD's mission. A final workshop report detailing the Workshop's findings was published and is available on line at http://www.nitrd.gov/nitrdgroups/images/2/2e/WSRD_Workshop_IV_Report.pdf. The agenda, attendance list, and video of the workshop are also available at: http://www.nitrd.gov/nitrdgroups/index.php?.title=Wireless_Spectrum_Research_and_Development_(WSRD)#WSRD_Workshop_IV
